I wanted to share my working just incase if someone confused at 1:50:05 @1:50:05  The question is asking for velocity, acceleration, and restoring force at x = 0.5m We know Vmax = 18.6 m/s and A = 1.5m and set the calculator in radiant mode  Method 1 -- By subs x = 0.5m into the formula v(specific time) = Vmax * sqrt(1 - x^2/A^2) This gives V(at x=0.5) = 17.536 m/s  Methods 2 -- If we want to use the V(t) equation we have to find the 'time' when the block at x=0.5 Using x(t) = 1.5 * Cos (12.4t), we subs the value 0.5 =  1.5 * Cos (12.4t), this gives t = 0.099271s Thus, subs t = 0.099271s into V(t) gives v(0.099271) = 18.6 Sin (12.4 * 0.099271) = 17.536 m/s (Same answer as Method 1)  This has been discussed before in the comment section but I hope I could clarify this again. I also wish someone could correct my working if I made any mistake.

you are excellent and it's difficult for me to say you made a mistake but you made a bit mistake when you find time t at x=0.5 and t at that position becomes t=5.6878s and as you do by substituting t=5.6878s into V(t)=-18.6Sin(12.4t) it gives V(5.6878s)=-18.6Sin(12.4*5.6878)=-18.6Sin(70.52)=-18.6*0.942=-17.53 m/s  If I made any mistake ,anybody could correct my working.

I also got v = 17.54 m/s at x = 0.5 m. I used the conservation of energy equation instead of using the derived velocity or acceleration functions.  Because x(t)=Acos(sqrt(k/m)t). We know the Amplitude is 1.5m and we can find k using 12.4=sqrt(k/m), k = 84.57, plug this into KE+PE=Total Energy. 0.5mv^2 + 0.5kx^2 =0.5kA^2. Solve for v, v=sqrt( (k/m)*(A^2-x^2) ), v = 17.54 m/s   For this you have to know (2pi)*frequency=sqrt(k/m)=the 12.4 in the x(t) cosine. 12.4 is also w, the angular frequency(lowercase omega) if you have learned this in class. w = sqrt(k/m) = (2pi)f  Watch the Crash Course or Flippin Physics on Simple Harmonic Motion if you didn't learn about angular frequency in class.

This video perfectly shows the frustrating part of physics. There is near zero convention for symbols. f can be frequency, unless it's friction. V can be frequency unless you're using f. KE can be kenetic energy but k can also be a constant in Hookes formula which can be written with or without the negative sign depending on your mood. w can be work unless it's actually a lower case omega.   And on and on. How have we not called a meeting and set some damn standards? Because the potential energy is equal to zero, since there is no deformation on the spring.

The equation is ME = KE + PE. Not sure where you got KE/ PE from but in this problem the spring is compressed 0.35m with a block of 0.25kg by a force of 500N. You would be right  saying PE=KE in this case (1/2(-)kx^2 = 1/2mv^) but in this case we are given A (0.35m and at the value of A we have all the energy as elastic potential energy and none as kinetic (V=0) and this point. But the second you release the spring all the energy becomes kinetic) and so he uses ME=KE (1/2ka^2 = 1/2mv^2) which is true the for the exact moment the spring is released since all the potential energy becomes kinetic energy.

You are a tremendous help. However, at 55:00 the exercise problem that you are solving, you mention that mechanical energy is equal to kinetic energy when the spring is released from compression. Yes.Precisely.

Hey, the negative is used when the F is referring to the restorative Force (ie the force of the spring). This is because the displacement vector is in the opposite direction of the Force vector. Ex. if you pull a spring to the right, the displacement is to the right, but the restorative force exerted by the spring is to the left. A positive value is used in cases of an applied force. Ex, if you apply 500 N to move the block to the right, direction of displacement and force are pointing in the same direction. In either case, k should always be a positive value whereas the signs of F and x depend on vector direction.

@CarochannSoba  Okay, thank you, I get all of that but I mean, an equation is an equation, so do we not always include the negative when stating the equation? They seem to cancel out anyway though, right? Or do you mean we should only use the negative sign if we are expressing the force as a vector, with an arrow on top?

It just depends on the context of the force! The equation is usually used to define force as force of the spring on the block in which case the negative is used, but it can also be used when a force is being used to move the object in the same direction (ex both point to the right) in which case a positive is used. I like to think of the two situations as applied force or restorative force.
@CarochannSoba  okay, I hear you, thank you. I think there is just a bit of a communication barrier but that is okay. Thank you for trying.

Jeez guys... So what you're saying is this: As the spring re-stretches to its original length (we compressed it  .35m) it PUSHES THE BLOCK at 0m/s?  This isn't really a harmonic problem,  there is no repetition. Once the spring has finished  re-stretching the .35m it was compressed, the block is free of the spring, thus no oscillation.  The Vmax formula works, however,  because the velocity after that  .35m is equal to Vmax of the harmonic motion of that spring if compressed .35m by 500N

mthokozisi njapha   I got t = 5.6878048s by graphing 0.5 = 1.5cos(12.4t) and y = 0.5. 5.6878048 is the intersection point.

well 0.5=1.5cos(12.4t) *divide both sides by 1.5  0.5/1.5=cos(12.4t) *shift cos   arc cos(or shift cos)(0.5/1.5)=12.4t *make t the subject of the formula  t=(cos^-1(0.5/1.5)/12.4 t= 5.687804788 therefore we can conclude by saying t is approximately 5.69 seconds
